reviewText:
Let's get it out of the way right off the bat. Yes, it's ugly as sin. I could say at least it's not pixel art" but that's just damning with faint praise. And the music is even worse.

But this captures the heart of Mystery Dungeon style games so well.

For those who don't know what that means
date: Mystery Dungeon is a brand of Japanese roguelikes dungeon crawlers (You may have seen the Shiren
hoursPlayed: or Etrian flavors). What makes them stand out is how simple they are compared to the western brand of roguelike. There are not six fiddly stats and 40 rings
helpfulPercent: and wands to manage nor are there 40 fiddly tricks to have to cover like keeping a wand of fire to scribble galadriel at opportune moments. You do not have to memorize 40 pages of spoilers and have "blessed +2 gray dragon scale mail" tattooed on your forearm.\n\nIn exchange for all that
votesHelpful: the genre focuses more on gamey style abilities. The wands and abilities you find control enemy pacing
commentsCount: etc. And when there is a horde of monsters bearing down on you with a monster that can paralyze you and another that can drain your levels
column16: your brain will be tested just like the best of roguelikes.\n\nSo what MD offers is something more innately intuitive and accessible than the overwrought and overfiddly roguelikes you may be accustomed to
column17: but one still quite difficult. If the western flavor is an enormous wargame run by steely-eyed grognards with fearsome neckbeards ready to debate tactics from the galactic wars of the far future to the Civil War
column18: MD is closer to chess.\n\nVoyage to Farland is almost a straight reskin of the DS Shiren game. Every ability
column20: with its own spin on balancing. If you can get past the atrocious art style
column21: you will find an excellent homage to a roguelike flavor that just is not well-represented on PC. Complete with Shiren's love of secrets and inventory management
column25: it is a wonderful homage from a fellow who is clearly as moved by Shiren as I am."
column29: 21 of 30 people (70%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: A roguelike for PC that actually feels like your playing a real Mystery Dungeon game! While the graphics are cute the game itself is extremely challenging. If you liked Shiren the Wanderer or any of the Torneko games then this game is for you!
voteText: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: The sprite and tile art are terrible- reminds me too much of the 90% of games in the GameMaker library.\n\nOther than that, it lives up to being like Chunsoft's Mystery Dungeon line of games as mentioned in the game's description, which is worth it if you grew up with those titles and don't care much for the game's visuals.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's not without issues such as a few graphical glitches and I personally hate the sprites in it but the game is fun and solid. It can be brutally hard even right at the start though.\n\nAs for the style of game it is, look to Pokemon Mystery Dungeon, Chocobo's Mysterious Adventure et al: basically Japanese console roguelikes.
voteText: 12 of 25 people (48%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: A fun roguelike in the Mystery Dungeon Style. Fight your way through the cute hordes of ultimate destruction and defeat the witch.\n\nHas nice retro graphics, some different game types, and sounds/music. I definitely recommend it to any roguelike and/or Shiren the Wanderer fan. Also available on Android.

reviewText: what this game lacks in graphics, music, polish and originality it more than makes up for in the way it copies the pokemon mysterie/shiren wanderer games I used to play on the DS, would definetly recommend

date: more RPGmaker-esque trash from a bundle. I guess that I should give it a try before giving it a bad review..."\n\n>Game is hideous
recommended:
even compared to the SNES game that started the series it's based on.

>Ugly transparent minimap directly on top of my ugly character.

>main controls are mapped to A and B
hoursPlayed:
which are nowhere near each other on the keyboard.

>First NPC I run into demands that we play rock-paper-scissors.
>There are insane button combinations to throw each sign.
>This is because the game is a sloppy port of a Nintendo DS homebrew game.
>If you lose to the NPC
voteText:
he tells you "I always win".
>This is not a clever meta joke about how this game is rigged against you - you're actually supposed to keep playing until you win an item off him.

Greenlight needs to be fixed to keep games like on Desura where they belong."
